I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Dialogue between the Government of Viet Nam and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
has highlighted the importance of providing timely support to the Ministry of Planning and 
Investment (MPI) on the preparation and implementation of the Socioeconomic Development 
Plan (SEDP), 2011–2015. An ADB fact-finding mission met with MPI officials in November 2010 
to prepare the technical assistance (TA) and reached an understanding with the government on 
its impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and 
terms of reference. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  In 2009, the government began preparing the SEDP, 2011–2015, which is scheduled to 
be approved by the National Assembly in November 2011. The government has committed to 
strengthening the results-based monitoring and evaluation (M&E) framework for the new SEDP. 
The government decision resulted from the work of an earlier ADB TA, Support for Results-
based Monitoring of Poverty Reduction and Growth, which identified significant challenges in 
results-based  poverty  monitoring  and  assessment.2 Although  poverty  reduction  and  social 
development indicators are used in Viet Nam, they are often used inconsistently, as evidenced 
by the mixed use of a variety of outcome and output indicators in the results framework. This 
earlier TA helped the government develop aggregate, sector, and local results indicators, as 
well as thematic indicators. These indicators formed part of the SEDP M&E framework that was 
issued by MPI on 30 May 2007 (Decision No. 555).3 The M&E results framework was developed 
in a participatory manner, through a series of national and provincial training seminars, and in 
consultation with experts, practitioners, managers, and development partners, especially the 
World Bank. Government officials were also trained on the concept and application of managing 
for development results (MfDR). The indicators that were developed were subsequently used for 
the midterm review of the SEDP, 2006–2010. 
 
3.  The completion report for Support for Results-based Monitoring of Poverty Reduction 
and  Growth  assessed  the  outcomes  of  the  TA  as  highly  satisfactory.  The  TA  contributed 
positively to ADB’s support for a broader MfDR agenda for public sector management (PSM) in 
Viet Nam. Results-based approaches in development planning and establishing indicators have 
been introduced. However, the lessons learned from the TA indicate that more needs to be 
done to ensure the implementation of Decision 555 to enable SEDP, 2011–2015 to use the 
M&E  framework  effectively.  The  framework  needs  to  support  the  planning,  budgeting, 
implementation, and evaluation dimensions of PSM. A robust PSM system will enable the 
government to make informed choices on resource allocation and will improve expenditure 
efficiency for more effective development.  
 
4.  SEDP, 2006–20104 identified opportunities to improve the SEDP planning approach, the 
structures and institutions, the M&E framework, including the use of appropriate indicators, as 
well as the use of information for crucial policy and program decision making. The opportunities 
include (i) promoting a better understanding of the benefits of results-based approaches in PSM, 
(ii) developing time-bound and measurable indicators, (iii) establishing baselines, (iv) collecting

and processing data, and (iv) analyzing and reporting results. Experience from implementing the 
SEDP, 2006–2010 also identified the need to link the development plan  to the budget and 
expenditures. The M&E framework of the development plan is directly linked, and contributes to, 
improved fiscal and financial management as it supports efficient budget allocations.  
 
5.  An important lesson learned during the SEDP, 2006–2010 period was the need to 
design and bring into operation the institutions and functions to implement Decision 555. The 
experience also showed that the M&E system is crucial to supporting decision making on 
policies, strategies, and budget allocations. 
 
6.  Significant work needs to be done under the SEDP, 2011–2015 to improve the M&E 
system  and  the  institutions  and  operations  needed  to  ensure  development  effectiveness. 
Strategic links with the budgetary process need to be put in place. Failure to address these 
issues may prevent the SEDP, 2011–2015 from delivering results. Viet Nam is an emerging 
economy and after steadily achieving good progress in reducing poverty over the last 20 years, 
it is well placed to incorporate results-based approaches into its PSM. A stronger M&E system 
is crucial to achieving this. The proposed TA will strengthen the existing M&E system, its 
institutions and functions, in addition to providing support for human resources development. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA will be improved implementation of the SEDP. The outcome will be 
a  better  M&E  system  for  the  SEDP,  with  reliable  and  timely  performance  monitoring  and 
reporting.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will involve a number of strategies and activities in successfully implementing the 
SEDP M&E system. The general strategy for the TA is to support and strengthen the existing 
system, begun under SEDP, 2006–2010. A number of operational strategies and actions will be 
used to strengthen the system and therefore SEDP, 2011–2015. The strategies are as follows: 
 
(i)  strengthening the understanding and appreciation of the dynamics of M&E and 
how it can be used strategically to strengthen SEDP planning, implementation, 
and results management; 
(ii)  reviewing and strengthening the design and conceptual validity and reliability of 
the existing SEDP M&E framework, including checking the existing indicators to 
ensure they are consistent with international good practices, and that data can be 
collected to monitor performance against them;  
(iii)  designing a robust and sustainable M&E implementation plan and accompanying 
mechanisms, tools, and techniques at policy and operational levels; 
(iv)  carrying out a participatory M&E development and prioritization exercise to obtain 
commitment from all key stakeholders; 
(v)  developing  technical  guidelines  and  manuals  for  operational  guidance  and 
capacity building; 
(vi)  carrying out structured and systematic technical and managerial capacity building 
for key institutions and stakeholders; 
(vii)   strengthening the sustainability of the M&E system through a training of trainers 
program  with  representation  from  key  institutions,  and  forging  strategic

3 
partnerships with training institutions, universities, and other service providers 
using a multifaceted capacity building strategy; 
(viii)  designing and building long-term initiatives that will be the foundation for broad-
based knowledge, appreciation, and use of M&E for development management; 
(ix)  identifying and setting up key institutional mechanisms at policy and operational 
levels; 
(x)  improving  operational  effectiveness  and  efficiency  at  policy  and  operational 
levels; 
(xi)  reviewing and strengthening the M&E system’s links with the SEDP, in particular 
the strategic links between development planning and budgeting, as well as how 
M&E supports both these functions; and 
(xii)  designing and initiating a structured program of change management at policy 
and operational levels to ensure that the transition to a full-fledged results-based 
SEDP and its M&E system can be achieved within specified timelines. 
 
9.  These strategies are based on the experience of implementing the SEDP M&E system 
as well as from international good practices. The main outcome of the strategies will be better 
results planning at both policy and operational levels. This includes a more concise national 
M&E  framework,  which  can  also  be  used  by  ministries  and  provinces.  Improved  use  of 
performance indicators at operational levels will lead to better results monitoring and reporting, 
which in turn will produce more timely and reliable results information for all SEDP development 
programs and projects. 
 
10.  The project will deliver three outputs: (i) a results-based M&E framework for SEDP, 
2011–2015,  (ii)  strengthened  institutional  and  functional  set  up;  and  technical  capacity  for 
relevant government officials; and (iii) a computerized M&E system.  
 
11.  Output 1: Results-based M&E framework for SEDP 2011–2015. It is crucial that the 
SEDP,  2011–2015  be  supported  by  an  effective  and  practical  M&E  system  covering  all 
programs and projects for the 5-year duration. This M&E system should be supported by a well 
defined, logically structured, and integrated M&E framework. The results-based framework will 
guide and ensure that the M&E system is able to support timely and reliable performance 
measurement and reporting by implementing agencies. The M&E framework will be designed 
and developed during the first year of the TA and is expected to be approved and operational by 
June 2013, at least in the MPI and in three other ministries. Output 1 will serve as the basis for 
output 2. 
 
12.  Output 2: Strengthened institutional and functional set up; and technical capacity 
for  relevant  government  officials.  An  M&E  framework  can  only  be  effective  if  it  is 
systematically linked to appropriate institutional and functional setups and the budgetary system. 
The TA will help to establish these links and to improve program and project officials’ M&E 
knowledge and skills. 
 
13.  Under the TA, about 400 key officials from policy-level entities and operational ministries 
and provinces will be trained in M&E and program and project management. The training of 
trainers  approach  will  be  used to  ensure  the capacity  building  in  M&E  is  sustained  in  all 
agencies. Appropriate technical guidelines and user manuals will be produced for the trainers 
and the agency officials. The first will be used for the training of trainers program. The second 
will be a users' manual on the M&E system to guide agencies in carrying out the M&E system 
under the SEDP.

4   
14.  Output 3: A computerized M&E system in selected agencies. The TA will provide 
technical support to computerize the revised SEDP M&E system. The TA will produce a cost-
effective computerized integrated solution to help ensure that the SEDP M&E system can 
capture  performance  data  at  each  implementation  level.  Consultations  with  stakeholders, 
including development partners, will be conducted to avoid potential system conflicts.  
 
15.  On the overall implementation of the proposed results-based integrated M&E system for 
the SEDP, it is proposed to adopt a comprehensive approach to government coverage. The 
integrated M&E system for the SEDP 2011–2015 will cover all ministries and provinces. This is 
appropriate as the same approach will be used for the SEDP, 2011–2015. To ensure effective 
and sustainable application of the system, implementation will phased. In the first year, the TA 
will focus on preparing the national SEDP framework and its implementation manual. In the 
second year, work will focus mainly on MPI and the most active ministries, while providing 
training for all agencies. During the third year, the TA will carry out further strengthening for the 
remaining ministries and provinces. The full implementation of the framework will be done in 
stages, with the initial phase focusing on improving the results framework and indicator sets, 
and trial performance monitoring and reporting. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,625,000 equivalent, of which $1,300,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will 
finance the remaining cost of $325,000 through in-kind contributions, which will cover office and 
support  facilities,  counterpart  staff,  administrative  support,  and  local  transportation  for 
counterpart staff. The cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MPI will be the executing agency and it will assign a vice minister to provide overall 
guidance to the TA. The vice minister will also chair the inception, midterm review, and final 
workshops.  The  Department  for  National  Economic  Issues  (DNEI)  under  MPI  will  be  the 
implementing agency and will directly supervise and implement the daily activities of the TA. 
MPI will provide office and counterpart staff to the TA; establish a project management unit 
comprising representatives from DNEI, the Foreign Economic Relations Department of MPI, and 
the General Statistics Office; and assign a project director from DNEI to oversee the project. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 36 months from January 2011 to December 2013. A 
total of 82 (20 international and 62 domestic) person-months of consulting services will be 
required. ADB will recruit an international M&E advisor, who will serve as the project team 
leader.  The  team  leader  will  be  supported  by  a  national  M&E  consultant,  an  information 
technology expert, and a project coordinator. The team leader will be recruited as an individual 
consultant. A firm will be engaged for three domestic consultant positions. This firm will be also 
in charge of procuring equipment, carrying out surveys, and training staff. Consultants will be 
engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). TA-financed equipment will be transferred to the executing agency 
at the conclusion of the TA. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
Disbursement under the TA project will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
19.  Regular  quarterly  progress  reports  will  be  produced  by  the  project.  These  will  be 
discussed by the project team and stakeholders, who will meet on a quarterly basis. Remedial

5 
actions, where needed, will be carried out by the project team based on feedback from the 
meeting. A tripartite meeting between the government, ADB and the consultants, chaired by the 
director general of DNEI, will be held every 6 months to review the progress of the project 
implementation and agree on the plan for the upcoming 6 months. 
 
20.  Key information on the project and its progress will be uploaded to a dedicated project 
website. The website will contain information on the outputs and outcome of the project and 
project evaluation results. The website will offer dynamic participation opportunities for those 
involved in similar projects within Viet Nam and in other countries. The website will also be used 
to support all ministries and provinces implementing the M&E system through discussion forums. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Support for the Preparation and Implementation of the Results-
Based Socioeconomic Development Plan 2011–2015 and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The proposed strengthening of the monitoring and evaluation (M&E) system for the 
forthcoming  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDP),  2011–2015  will  provide  important 
support  to  Viet  Nam’s  efforts  to  improve  governance.  It  will  review  and  strengthen  the 
development planning system and frameworks to make the M&E system more effective and 
efficient. This review is fundamental to improving the performance of the country’s SEDP over 
the next 5 years. 
 
2.  The overall aim of the review and adjustments to the development planning approach, 
structure, and system as a whole is to promote the successful implementation of the SEDP. 
This will only be possible if there is a sound M&E system that sets clear and realistic indicators 
and measurements that can be addressed.  
 
3.  Several steps need to be performed before the revised system and tools can be fully 
functional. The actions should be carried out gradually to ensure efficient adoption of the revised 
M&E system, leading to improved implementation of the SEDP, 2011–2015. 
 
4.  The project team will comprise an international M&E advisor and team leader, supported 
by three national consultants (M&E expert, project coordinator, and information technology 
expert), as well as clerical support. Details of the proposed project team members and their 
roles and responsibilities are provided below. 
 
5.  International M&E advisor and team leader (international, 20 person-months). The 
team leader will plan, implement, and achieve the planned outcomes for the project. As team 
leader, the consultant will:  
 
(i)  provide overall oversight and management of the project; 
(ii)  carry out strategic planning in consultation with the government and the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB); 
(iii)  plan  the  activities  of  the  project  and  undertake  high-level  communication, 
coordination, and liaison work with key government agencies involved with the 
project; 
(iv)  review and advise on the structure and contents of the SEDP results framework 
as well as the integrity of the indicators in the framework and their measurement; 
(v)  advise  on  good  practices  in  formulating  indicators,  implementing  strategies, 
collecting  data,  and  generating  information  for  improved  policy  and  program 
decision making under the SEDP; 
(vi)  share with and obtain feedback from all relevant government agencies on all 
aspects of the project; 
(vii)  regularly  monitor  and  evaluate  the  project  and  ensure  timely  and  reliable 
performance data collection for the project; 
(viii)  provide periodic performance reports to the key stakeholders; 
(ix)  oversee and manage all personnel matters for the project, including providing 
guidance on work planning and performance of national consultants and other 
project personnel; and 
(x)  provide strategic inputs on issues and contextual matters to the project. 
 
6.  As  the  international  M&E  advisor,  the  consultant  will  take  overall  responsibility  for 
advising and guiding the design and implementation of the revised M&E system for the SEDP, 
2011–2015 and on national development planning. The services of the advisor will be needed

Appendix 3  11 
as soon as possible in view of the ongoing review of the SEDP by the Ministry of Planning and 
Investment (MPI). The international M&E consultant will help MPI conceptualize, design, and 
develop the integrated M&E system for the SEDP, 2011–2015. 
7.  The advisor will help the MPI and other key agencies with the strategic planning and 
implementation of the integrated M&E system, and all related actions. This will include advice 
on  the  review  and  strengthening  of  the  current  SEDP  planning  approach,  structures,  and 
systems to make them compatible with and supportive of the revised M&E system. 
 
8.  The advisor will be the principal mentor to the MPI and other key agencies on the 
restructuring and strengthening of the integrated development planning approach and system. 
He or she will also serve as the principal advisor for the SEDP M&E system. 
 
9.  The advisor will give advice to ADB on its country partnership strategy (CPS) for the 
duration of the SEDP, 2011–2015, specifically on ADB’s own monitoring and reporting of its 
CPS to ensure that it is compatible with the SEDP M&E system. The advisor will provide 
technical inputs intensively for the first 2 years during the early period of the SEDP. After the 
first 2 years, the inputs of the advisor will be reduced. His or her inputs are expected to be 
intermittent over the consultancy period. 
 
10.  Project support firm. The TA deliverables require close administrative and logistical 
support  for  the  project  team  to  ensure  that  the  project  can  be  implemented  with  optimal 
efficiency and effectiveness. The prescribed project deliverables will require detailed planning 
and  various  preparatory  and  implementation  actions.  These  include  the  sourcing  and 
recruitment of three national consultants, as well as a range of other project-related actions 
such  as  procuring  project  equipment,  conducting  surveys  and  training,  as  well  as  various 
administrative responsibilities related to project management. 
11.  To ensure the smooth functioning of the project and the expected results, a firm will be 
engaged to help ADB and the team leader manage the project. Specifically, the firm will:  
 
(i)  support the team leader with administrative and logistical support as prescribed 
in the project plan; 
(ii)  recruit  and  contract  three  national  consultants  and  other  relevant  service 
providers for project actions such as surveys and training; 
(iii)  be accountable for the quality and performance of the national consultants; 
(iv)  procure and maintain the project equipment; 
(v)  carry out prescribed surveys and studies as prescribed under the project; 
(vi)  organize and coordinate relevant project-related training; 
(vii)  provide administrative support to the project team; 
(viii)  prepare  and  submit  project  progress  and  financial  reports  to  ADB  and  the 
government; and  
(ix)  oversee the contracts of the national consultants. 
 
12.  The firm will carry out its duties and responsibilities with due diligence and efficiency and 
deliver to ADB such information related to the services as the ADB may reasonably request.   
 
13.  National M&E consultant (national, 15 person-months). The national consultant will 
work closely with the international M&E consultant in designing and developing the integrated 
M&E system and the revised development planning and results framework for the SEDP, 2011–
2015. The  consultant will  help  the  international  M&E  consultant  with  the  capacity  building

activities for the ministries and provinces as well as with all training development work. The 
consultant will work with the international M&E consultant during missions and provide local 
content and knowledge to the project and in the design and implementation of the M&E system. 
14.  Over the period of the project, the consultant will work closely with the international M&E 
consultant in carrying out all planned activities under the strategic directions of the international 
M&E consultant. The duties and responsibilities of the national consultant are as follows: 
 
(i)  help  the  international  M&E  consultant  design,  develop,  and  implement  the 
integrated results-based M&E system for the SEDP, 2011–2015; 
(ii)  provide local content and advice to the international M&E consultant on any 
special characteristics and requirements for the local context; 
(iii)  carry out any needed research work related to the SEDP M&E system and 
related aspects; 
(iv)  carry out any special survey and data collection, including baseline data, that 
may be required under the project; 
(v)  carry out any liaison work with MPI, other key policy agencies and other line 
agencies and/or provinces related to the project; 
(vi)  help the international M&E consultant design and draw up an appropriate training 
program for the SEDP M&E system; prepare and check the quality of all training 
materials for the training on the M&E system; and help in the training and other 
capacity-building activities under the project; 
(vii)  help  the  international  M&E  consultant  with  the  design  of  an  integrated 
computerized M&E system for the SEDP; 
(viii)  help  the  international  M&E  consultant  with  all  other  activities  related  to  the 
revised M&E system for the SEDP;  
(ix)  help with the monitoring, evaluation, and reporting of the project performance to 
the stakeholders as and when required, and assist in the preparation of project 
performance reports from time to time; and 
(x)  help the international M&E consultant with other project-related matters as and 
when required. 
 
15.  M&E project coordinator (national, 32 person-months). The TA will support a series 
of actions and activities at the MPI and other agencies and provinces. The project team will also 
need to interact and work closely with the key program officials at the ADB Viet Nam resident 
mission, since part of the TA extension work also covers the review and streamlining of the 
results framework in ADB’s CPS for the period of the SEDP, 2011–2015. It is envisaged that a 
full-time project coordinator will be required to support the project team in terms of overall 
coordination of the project operations. The project coordinator will 
 
(i)  review and manage the project budget and expenses; 
(ii)  help monitor the project and activities and performance reporting; and 
(iii)  be responsible for all other liaison work regarding the project. 
 
16.  The project coordinator will report directly to the international M&E consultant on all 
office matters, and work closely with and be guided by him or her on all project matters, 
including when the international M&E consultant is off-site.
